Competition Is for Losers

Why the best businesses escape competition entirely

By Peter Thiel

Stanford University Lecture

What does competition actually look like in the startup world? How can young businesses be competitive? And is our society's relationship with competition healthy? Peter Thiel, co-founder of PayPal and early investor in Facebook, answered these questions during his Stanford University lecture.

Creating Value vs. Capturing Value

Compare the airline industry to the search industry. By size, airlines seem more important. But look at profit margins, and the picture flips entirely.

Airlines
~$200B
Revenue (but razor-thin margins)
Google
4x
Market cap of all airlines combined

Airlines make money, go bankrupt, get recapitalized, and repeat the cycle. The combined market capitalization of the entire airline industry is close to just a quarter of Google's. Even though search is a much smaller industry than air travel, it's actually more valuable.

"You have to create something of value and capture some fraction of the value you've created."

This is the fundamental equation of business: creating value is not the same as capturing value. Airlines create enormous value for society. They just don't capture much of it.

The Binary World of Business

Thiel sees the business world as a binary. On one end: industries that are perfectly competitive. On the other end: monopolies. "There is shockingly little that is in between."

Monopolies

More stable, long-term businesses with more capital. If you get a creative monopoly for inventing something new, it often means you've created something really valuable.

  • High profit margins
  • Pricing power
  • Long-term durability
  • Capital to reinvest

Perfect Competition

Easy to model and efficient in a static world. But perfect competition doesn't make money when a lot of competition is involved.

  • All firms sell identical products
  • No one controls price
  • Small market shares
  • Freedom of entry and exit

The Lies We Tell

Both monopolies and non-monopolies are tempted to lie, but in opposite directions.

Monopolies Pretend to Have Lots of Competition

They don't want the government to regulate them, so they won't call themselves a monopoly. They position themselves in expansive markets where there's "competition everywhere."

Example: Google has 66% market share in search. But you'll never hear them describe themselves as a search engine. They call themselves an "advertising company" or a "technology company." The technology market is valued at close to $1 trillion, so suddenly they're competing with car companies, Apple, Microsoft, and Amazon.

Non-Monopolies Pretend to Have No Competition

Companies in highly competitive industries say they're doing something unique to attract capital. They define their market as narrowly as possible to seem like they have a monopoly.

Example: A new restaurant (notoriously bad investments) rebrands as "the only British food restaurant in Palo Alto." That's too small of a market. But the way they talk about it, they seem to have a monopoly.

The Distortion

"In a world where monopolists pretend not to have monopolies and non-monopolies pretend to have monopolies, it seems like the difference between the two is very small. But in reality, the real difference is vast. These lies produce a distortion of the business world."

Go After Small Markets

If you're a startup, you want to have a monopoly. But how do you get there?

  1. 1
    Start with a really small market

    The biggest mistake is going after a giant market from the get-go. That signifies you haven't defined categories correctly.

  2. 2
    Take over said market

    Dominate your niche completely before expanding.

  3. 3
    Expand in concentric circles

    Move into adjacent markets once you've won the first one.

Even Amazon started with just a bookstore. Their selling point was that they had all the books in the world for sale online. After they established themselves as a bookstore, they expanded into different types of e-commerce.

"You don't want to be the fourth online pet food company. You don't want to be the tenth solar panel company. All unhappy companies are alike because they failed to escape the essential sameness in competition."

Last Mover Advantage

Thiel disagrees with Silicon Valley's notion that you need to be the first mover. Instead, you need to be the best and the last.

Microsoft
Last operating system (for decades)
Google
Last search engine
Facebook
Last social network

Why do last movers succeed? Because most of the value in these companies exists far in the future.

When Thiel was at PayPal in 2001, they were growing at 100% per year. But three quarters of the business value as of 2001 came from cash flows in 2011 and beyond. For companies like Airbnb, Twitter, and Facebook, the math says 85% of value comes from cash flows in 2024 and beyond.

Durability Over Growth

We need to stop overvaluing growth and undervaluing durability. Everybody wants a eureka moment. But unless your breakthrough is the final breakthrough, you won't last. You need to think about who will be the leading company 10 to 20 years from now.

Why Competition Is for "Losers"

Not every successful invention makes the inventor rich. Scientists are seldom adequately rewarded for their advances. Einstein wasn't a billionaire.

The rationale is that scientists aren't interested in money. But Thiel questions this: if people at Twitter make billions, does that mean Twitter is worth more than anything Einstein did? This type of rationalization is dangerous.

"We think of losers as people who are slow on the track team or don't get into the right schools. But maybe the competition itself is off. It's no longer a form of validation."

Thiel sees competition as both an intellectual and psychological blind spot. We're attracted to competition. We find it reassuring when other people do things. This is problematic.

Thiel's Personal Story

In eighth grade, a friend wrote in his yearbook: "I know you're going to get into Stanford." He did, attending Stanford Law School, then ending up at a big New York law firm.

"From the outside everybody wanted to get in, and on the inside everybody wanted to leave."

He left after seven months. His colleagues applauded him, even though for him it was a simple choice.

The Core Insight

"So much of people's identities got wrapped up in winning these competitions that they somehow lost sight of what was important, what was valuable."

Key Takeaways for Sales Leaders

  1. 1
    Creating value is not capturing value

    Your product might be incredibly valuable. The question is: can you capture the value you create, or does competition give it all away?

  2. 2
    Define your market honestly

    If you're a monopoly, don't advertise it. If you're in a competitive market, don't pretend you have a monopoly.

  3. 3
    Dominate small markets first

    Own your niche completely, then expand. Going after big markets too early means too much competition.

  4. 4
    Be the last, not the first

    First mover advantage is overrated. What matters is being the best and most durable.

  5. 5
    Question competition itself

    Don't assume competition validates your path. Sometimes the tournament doesn't make sense.
